body:
>`update_predict_single` no longer refits the model in v0.10.1

Thanks for reporting, @atsangarides!

I briefly looked into the base class, and it does seem that `update_predict_single` calls `update` by default, which calls the inner `_update`. The latter has as default "refitting on the entire data seen so far".

So from a framework perspective, it seems that refitting/updating is hardcoded and also done as a default (if all works as intended).

What could be the case, is that individual models override this incorrectly and don't update despite the interface looking like it would.

So, could you kindly paste some reproducible code, and let us know whether you think it's a particular model, or whether it's a general problem? If you think it's a general problem, can you explain why you think it is?

I have included my model below to see if something stands out for you. Cannot provide my data I am afraid. If still not clear will try with other datasets...

```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sktime.forecasting.base import BaseForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.compose import TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.transformations.series.impute import Imputer
from sktime.transformations.series.outlier_detection import HampelFilter
from sktime.transformations.series.adapt import TabularToSeriesAdaptor
from sklearn.preprocessing import FunctionTransformer
from sktime.forecasting.theta import ThetaForecaster


model = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    steps=[
        # avoid <=0 values that multiplicative seasonality cannot handle
        ("neg", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(
            FunctionTransformer(np.clip, kw_args={"a_min": 0.01, "a_max": None})
        )
         ),
        # filter out peaks
        ("filter", HampelFilter(window_length=24*7, n_sigma=5)),
        # fill NaNs introduced by filter above
        ("impute", Imputer("forecaster", forecaster=NaiveForecaster("drift"))),
        ("forecast", ThetaForecaster(sp=24))
    ]
)

# this does not work
model.fit(X=None, y=y_train) # works as expected
forecasts = model.predict_update_single(X=None, y=y_new, update_params=True) # does not refit

# this works 
model.fit(X=None, y=y_train) 
y_updated = pd.concat([model._y, y_new])
model.fit(X=None, y=y_updated)
forecasts = model.predict(...)
```

Hmmmm - on first glance, there is a lot of composition here, and in a pipeline the "update" is called sequentially. So it would in theory suffice if it is broken in one of the estimators only, or in the compositors (e.g., the pipeline) for it to break overall.

@aiwalter, do you have any obvious idea? Given that it´s using a number of estimators I think you might be familiar with?
also, quick question, @atsangarides, how do you know it does not refit?

thanks for looking into this @fkiraly !
I use `prefect` for scheduling daily updates. I did a backfill using bumped sktime `0.10.1` and these are the results (see below). Good performance is up to the original training period; the rest is backfilled daily updates..
I manually tested the code above to investigate, `predict_update_single` is way too fast. `._y` does get appended with new observations, but there is no refit.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42976901/159992817-777c8714-75bb-421d-a25e-cba69523b9e5.png)

Ouch - I hope this didn't incur any trading losses 😅 
(I just compulsively had to look up the "IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT HOLDER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE" part of our BSD license 😁)

I think I found the error - the `_update` of the `TransformedTargetForecaster` calls `update` of the transformers, but not `transform`! It should be calling, in sequence of the pipeline, `trafo1.update`, `trafo1.transform`, `trafo2.update`, `trafo2.transform`, and passing results of `transform` on to the next `update` and `transform`. But instead, it updates everything on the untransformed data.

At least, that's *a* bug. It would not explain why the updating runs in no time, but it would explain why the output is garbage.

ok, I was going crazy!
I did follow the code trail you did in your first step, and could see the updated and predict steps.
It's just weird that the behaviour of the transformer (/steps) changed over the bump and I couldn't find it.
yes, I think it's coming from `TransformedTargetForecaster` and not from the framework. @aiwalter, would much appreciate your (author's) eyes on this, too!

Btw, I think it's also broken in the `ForecastingPipeline`. Just to confirm whether it's not me getting confused here: the `update` of `trafoN` needs to be called on the output of `transform` of `trafo[N-1]`, and not on the input, does that sound correct?

issue.title: [BUG] fixing forecasting pipelines `update`

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR (hopefully) fixes the bug reported in #2291, and a parallel bug in `ForecastingPipeline`.

This is based on the assumption that the bug in #2291 is caused by incorrect implementation of `update` in `TransformedTargetForecaster`, where `transform` of the transformers in the pipeline were not being called, and all `update` were called on the input data.

Depends on #2300 which fixes an issue arising from current tests causing empty `y` being passed to `update` when `update_predict` is called within those tests, which is encountered by the fix.

body:
> It's just weird that the behaviour of the transformer (/steps) changed over the bump and I couldn't find it.

Are you saying, it changed in one of the recent versions?

You're right about how that would behave, assuming `_update` was added sometime recently.
If the `_update` wouldn't be there in the pipelines, it would just revert to default behaviour specified in the base class framework (`BaseForecaster`), and just continue updating by fitting to the entire data (without calling any implemented `update` functionality of the steps).

That's computationally more wasteful than calling `update`, but ... at least it's correct ...

Anyway, I guess we're lucky that we found this 1 day before the new release. If this is indeed the fix, it should be included in the new, much improved 😄 0.11.0 version.

> It would not explain why the updating runs in no time, but it would explain why the output is garbage.

I'm noticing, my sentence above give an explanation to the "no time" aspect - calling `update` is usually much faster than a complete refit, so it fits the explanation:

it's faster because `update` is being called now instead of a `fit` to the entire data, so it's faster. Just on incorrect inputs...

So, here's a question: tests are not catching this currently, because, even though `update` returns garbage, it returns garbage in the expected data format, which the test think is fine. The tests have no means to pick up a garbage estimator, because the garbage could be intentional and hence "correct". Any good ideas about the testing problem here?

Oh. Will hold off from changing my pipeline flows then! Was changing to separate fit/predict steps!
Don't know if my suggestion is of any value re tests.. Internally we tend to test transformations.. i.e. using some static/hardcoded data do we get the transformed values we expect. A dead simple series of transformations you can apply and test input<>output data?

> 
> Are you saying, it changed in one of the recent versions?
> 

It was working as expected on `0.9.0`

>A dead simple series of transformations you can apply and test input<>output data?

Yes, we do that in parts of the code base already, most prominently in time series classification.
FYI @MatthewMiddlehurst (we had been discussing this recently).
Perhaps we should also do this in forecasting.

Although it would primarily detect whether the logic of the pipeline has *changed*, not whether it produces *garbage*, so it's not quite the same? Perhaps sth tied to performance monitoring?
